Larger volume bc of how ARP/IRA were financed, but I’m not sure historic averages of short/long-term debt by maturity
Dang while I was writing a thread you said it better than me

At the consumer level, higher rates for mortgages, higher costs as inflation/higher rates raise other essentials, bleeds into increasing consumer debt delinquency. Potential for vicious cycle of bankruptcies -> unemployment -> decreased spending -> bankruptcies… bad news! (4/4)

4. Impact: at the federal level, our ability to deficit-finance a crisis (major war, depression, another pandemic) is much more expensive and much more constrained. Economically, businesses refinancing debt will have to pay much more, debt-intensive sectors hardest hit. (3/4)

3. We are now paying much more to finance new debt due to deficit spending, and 30% of older treasury securities (bills/notes/bonds) expired in 2023, which means we are refinancing marketable (fixed-rate) debt at MUCH higher rates. (2/4)
Rec reading: research.stlouisfed.org/publ…

Totally fair request. Lemme try:
1. Fed raises rates from practically zero to 5.5% to tamp down inflation bc of COVID stimulus/ARP/IRA
2. Inflation trends lower, but high rates mean new gov’t debt (either bc of deficit spending or old debt rolling over) has higher interest. (1/4)

We are marching towards financial peril while politicians squabble over petty grievances. It’s long past time we elect leaders who are willing to level with the American people on the macroeconomic dangers before us and work to enact lasting reform before it’s too late. (2/2)

In other news, this is bad. Real bad. It’s why interest payments on our national debt will soon surpass our (massive) defense budget. And why mortgage rates won’t be going down anytime soon. And why commercial real estate and bond markets are getting hairy. And worse. (1/2)
Is there any explanation for this post that isn’t absolutely vile?
Objectively, getting murdered is worse than getting carjacked.
Not as tragic as the 212 homicides in DC so far in 2023, but an awful reminder of how dangerous DC is becoming.
Congratulations!

Grey’s Law explains 90%+ of modern politics. 

This whole Bowman episode has also irreparably undermined my efforts to convince people that most members of Congress are not nearly as dumb as they seem on TV. Many are actually pretty smart!
To be clear- not normal for members to go through doors that had been closed with those signs on them. At a minimum, that was dumb. Normal reaction would be to turn around and find another way.
Fastest route from Cannon HOB to Capitol is outside across Independence Ave

In sum, pulling the fire alarm was very dumb. Now Bowman will have to explain whether he did a dumb thing for dumb reasons (open door) or dumb thing for bad reasons (obstruct/delay). Fwiw, I’m here: “Never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity.” 6/6

But pulling the fire alarm in a House Office Building wouldn’t disrupt anything happening in Capitol/other buildings. If his intent (as some allege) was to delay votes, this was a dumb way to do it. Then again, the only other explanation is dumb too! 5/6

However, it makes ZERO sense that he’d think the fire alarm would open doors- they are emergency exits, just push them open! And if he pulled the fire alarm bc was worried about triggering an alarm by pushing the doors open, well- alarms don’t, like, cancel each other out. 4/6

If this entrance is blocked, the next fasted route from Cannon to the Capitol is to take one flight of stairs down to the tunnel. Marginally less direct, maybe ~5min trip vs ~3min. Could make difference btwn missing a vote and not. 3/6

While Congress was in session, it was the weekend/unexpected and this entrance (looks like NJ Ave) is a main entrance normally, and the fastest above-ground route from Cannon offices to the Capitol. If Bowman was late for votes, it would make sense he would rush this way. 2/6

Background detail that may be helpful:
USCP closes some House office building entrances at night/on the weekends/when Congress is not in session to ease workload on personnel. Those doors still function as exits for fire purposes (have alarm bars to open from inside). 1/6
From USCP
I had a 3 month MOS re-class training (needed to be eligible to deploy w/ a new unit) canceled on 3 days’ notice bc of that. Knocked me out of an Afghanistan rotation.
How pathetic. There must be severe consequences for this.

I don’t believe in binaries and try to give credit where credit is due. I think the idea that if one has taken (strong!) issue with things Trump has done means one must reflexively approve and affirm what Biden is doing is itself a cynical gambit I reject.

His defense of keeping Ilhan Omar on the House Foreign Affairs Committee asked legit questions and raised strong points that only a handful of other members did. The public would be better served if more issues were subject to detailed debates rather than tired talking points.

There are a lot of funny pragmatists in Congress but their speech is neutered by the reality of primaries. I enjoyed torturing other members’ chiefs/comms directors by praising how funny their member was and saying their member should control their twitter. Their response:

Thank you. I meant that a lot of folks who otherwise hate Gaetz were giving grudging admiration, as if they were surprised he was funny. My point is that when approval/disapproval of a person’s views/approach bleeds into other attributes it has a distorting effect.
I lost my primary. Pretty sure I’ve already de-based myself.

Consistency and political expediency rarely go hand-in-hand, but Gaetz has also staked out and fiercely defended unpopular positions (like objecting to GOP efforts to remove Ilhan Omar from the House Foreign Affairs Committee).
Please define ‘this.’ My tweet? Matt Gaetz’s argument? A government shutdown?

Don’t believe me? Watch his Sunday interview with Maria Bartiromo. You can or disagree with his points, but Gaetz is no slouch when it comes to both articulating and defending his position in hostile settings. (2/2)

Seeing from the reaction to this, it seems a lot of folks don’t appreciate @mattgaetz is both (a) witty and (b) a sharp orator. And unlike a lot of other politicians’ clever social media posts or carefully-crafted one-liners, I’m pretty sure he writes his own content. (1/2)

I have been consistent in my defense of the concept of withdrawing- my problem is with the ‘damn the torpedoes’ approach to withdrawal of this admin, the laggardly approach to evacuating allies post 8/30/21, and the lack of engagement with post-Ghani AFG government.

Kudos to Gen McKenzie. I think this is the most contrition expressed by any senior official involved in this disastrous withdrawal- and in stark contrast to @SecDef’s galling “no regrets” comment re withdrawal from March.
#onepride

Can you offer a definition of ‘insurrection or rebellion’ that encompasses the Civil War + Jan 6 that doesn’t also loop in a bunch of chaos from the summer of 2020 or other civil unrest?

Unless there are indisputable grounds for candidate ineligibility (age, citizenship status, etc), state officials choosing to disqualify federal candidates on subjective grounds will lead this country down an even darker and more dangerous road than the outcome they fear. (2/2)

This. @petespiliakos says it more elegantly than I did (“asshattery”). Shifting the 14th A/clause 3 understanding of ‘insurrection or rebellion’ from the Civil War to whatever a political official decides is an insurrection/rebellion is an *incredibly* slippery slope. (1/2)

Video highlights range of states, but I’d bet @SpeakerMcCarthy asked what city they were from and knew it’s congressional district, PVI, median income, % college educated, major industries, and probably a handful of pieces of political trivia to boot. The man knows districts!

Smart move by @MINationalGuard, especially after the horrific tragedy in Maui. While wildfires are not the only risk, it’s worth remembering that Michigan holds the somber record of having the US’ fourth deadliest fire- the Thumb Fire of 1882 that killed 282 Michiganders.
“For my friends, sympathy. For my enemies- the law.”

You know that power utilities are granted government-sanctioned monopolies, right? They are among the most highly regulated sectors of our economy. There are some logical reasons for this, but it is anything but free-market capitalism.

You know that power utilities are granted government-sanctioned monopolies, right? They are among the most highly regulated sectors of our economy. There are some logical reasons for this, but it is anything but free-market capitalism.
And we have the highest electricity costs in the Midwest!

What works to make housing cheaper: 
-reduce soft costs (permitting reform- hard bc takes power from D bureaucrats)
-reduce material costs (by slashing tariffs- ditto above)
-reduce labor costs (lol)
-lower interest rates (impossible w/DC Ds juicing inflation w/huge spending) 2/2

Rent control can stabilize costs for current tenants- whose artificially-low housing costs are then subsidized by *much higher* costs for new renters. Not a solution.

As a rule, taking cues from New York & California housing policies won’t make Michigan housing affordable. 1/2

CNN broadcast me saying “spare me that sanctimonious bullshit” (re Dem meddling in my race) and it surprised me. But cable has rules set internally and broadcast/radio by FCC (I have also cussed on satellite radio I believe)

You ask as if I haven’t researched what light profanities I can or cannot say on FCC-regulated media. (Spoiler: derivations of ‘ass’ or ‘shit’ are no-gos, including asshattery and bullshit, though there are vague allowances of speech has ‘literary, political, or artistic value’.)

Relative to plastic straws, paper straws:

In answer to both, it’s not clear that RUS/Wagner forces can conventionally escalate in Ukraine (low munitions, many SOF/highly trained combatants KIA, etc). Belarus is already used to attack Ukraine; could be used more, but RUS forces stretched thinner than UKR.

Unless something totally wild happens, like Prigozhin succeeding Lukashenko and turning Belarus into a Wagner pirate state to assault Ukraine and harass Baltic states, it’s hard to see any 3D chess here. Just a desperate oligarch salvaging what he can.
So this whole thing resolves (for now) with a deal that basically causes everyone to lose face? Putin looks weak, Prigozhin backed down, MoD ‘leadership changes’…

Russian factions turning their guns against each other means fewer guns attacking Ukraine, and a weaker/distracted force makes escalation less likely. Right to fear consequences of leadership change in Moscow- *that* sends us into a frightening unknown.

Afghanistan’s future is yet to be written, but the unscripted dialogue here offers hope of transparency from a regime that errs on the side of secrecy + a way to address justifiable skepticism from a wary Afghan public. Credit all around for this frank and honest exchange. (3/3)

Yaqoob, son of legendary Taliban leader Mohammad Omar, was until 2021 as mysterious as his father (of whom only two photos existed). Less than 2 yrs later, he sits for an 1.5 hr interview. Sure, some deflection (typical of any political figure) but surprising candor too. (2/3)

I recognize few will watch all 78 minutes of this @TOLOnews interview with acting Minister of Defense Mohammad Yaqoob Mujahid, but it’s fascinating: hard-hitting questions from a seasoned Afghan reporter to a Taliban leader on difficult subjects. (1/3)

It’s so annoying when lazy hacks like this guy dredge up the ‘ole “lifetime pension” canard when it applies to any federal employee. Members hear this myth so often that some like @RepScottPerry even have helpful FAQs! (3/3) perry.house.gov/how-can-scot…

FERS pension amount depends on yrs of SVP & calculated based on avg salary in final 3 yrs. So if Lauren is re-elected and retires after her third term, she would be eligible to receive a $17,588 pension in [checks notes] 2050, likely less than 1/3 of social security then. (2/3)

At the risk of giving a jackass attention, context: Members of Congress pay 1.2% of their salary into the Federal Employees’ Retirement System (FERS). Members, like any fed employee, are eligible for a pension if they’ve served at least 5 years- but not until they turn 62. (1/3)

One of the best antidotes for conspiratorial thinking is being a part of institutions outsiders claim are insidious and calculating. After a decade in MI and a term in Congress, I have yet to meet anyone with the discipline and intelligence to pull off 1% of what QAnon claims.
It deeply offends my nativist flora sensibilities.

Apparently you can eat the leaves, but the important thing is to get them out of natural habitats. I filled up two contractor bags with pulled garlic mustard last year and have already filled half of another this year.

The plants can be really small or really big, but what’s important is you rip them out before each flowering plant makes thousands of seeds. The seeds can stay in the soil for up to a decade before sprouting, so check every year! canr.msu.edu/news/garlic_mus…

PSA: It’s the perfect time of the year to eradicate invasive garlic mustard plants before they seed. These bastards may have pretty white flowers, but they crowd out and harm native plants. Pull it out at the base to get the full root and toss in the trash (DO NOT COMPOST!)

This inconsistency is easily explained- @POTUS prob didn’t know about this graphic tweeted from his official account, which combines R boogeymembers (in D eyes) w/ Republicans on DCCC target list. Pretty gross misuse of official resources, but that’s par for course w/Biden.
Fair point, though degree of outlandishness is a subjective question. On the objective facts of an indictment, McCarthy is following well-established precedent.
This is standard; precedent is that members of Congress under indictment are removed from committees, and that they resign (or expelled if they fail to resign) in the event of a conviction.
Missed that on first viewing; with this new information, crucifixion is certainly called for.
